comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Dr. Bradfield, seen here in the centre of the photograph with his profile to the camera, is also seen in a photograph of a more ceremonial mark by the surveyors at Government House assisted by Sir Dudley de Chair on the same day, 17/03/1925:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2733891381/]

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Good spot; you have a good memory! And very thoughtful of Bradfield to wear such a distinctive hat. 

These two photos are from our SHB set (I will update the caption) and now I'm wondering how many others Dr JJC Bradfield appears in... 

AB

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw]
I know those books came to State Records NSW  via the Bradfield family in 1968 (series 12685) - and as such it seems likely that Dr. Bradfield had a hand in their composition and compilation.

 From the blocks of granite quarried at Moruya in 1926

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2849924824/]

to the first train over the bridge in 1932

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5691268185]

He had a way of making sure he was in the picture.

comment.author: 78191524@N07
comment._content: Hi State Records NSW, I've published the above 'Surveyors at work, 1925' picture by you in an article on my blog at the following link: www.roomelegance.com/what-on-earth-is-a-land-survey-and-w... Please visit the article at the link above and see if you like it. Thanks for the nice image. Sandy.
